question: The Aravali, standing alone, offers panoramic views of the surrounding plains.
solution:
The error in the sentence is with the article "The Aravali".

Correction:

‚ùå The Aravali ‚Üí ‚úÖ Aravali

Reason:

  • "Aravali" is a mountain range, and generally, mountain ranges do not take the definite article "The" unless they are plural (e.g., The Himalayas, The Andes).
  • Correct usage: "Aravali, standing alone, offers panoramic views of the surrounding plains."

However, if referring to a specific peak or part of the range, "The Aravali Hills" or "The Aravali Range" would be acceptable.

Rule for Using "The" with Mountains & Mountain Ranges
The usage of "The" with mountains depends on whether we are referring to individual mountains or mountain ranges.

Individual Mountains (No "The")
When referring to a single mountain, we do not use "The".
‚úÖ Correct:
Mount Everest
Mount Fuji
Kilimanjaro
Kanchenjunga
‚ùå Incorrect:
‚ùå The Mount Everest
‚ùå The Kilimanjaro
2. Mountain Ranges (Use "The")
When referring to a range of mountains, we use "The" before the name.
‚úÖ Correct:
The Himalayas
The Alps
The Andes
The Aravali Hills
‚ùå Incorrect:
‚ùå Himalayas are beautiful. (Should be The Himalayas)
‚ùå Alps are in Europe. (Should be The Alps)
3. Exceptions
Some mountain names do not follow the standard rule:
The Matterhorn (Even though it's a single peak, "The" is used)
The Rockies (Short for "The Rocky Mountains")

question: Guitar is one of the most popular musical instruments in the world.
solution:
The corrected sentence would be: "The guitar is one of the most popular musical instruments in the world."

Rule for Using "the" with Musical Instruments:

We use "the" before musical instruments in both general and specific contexts when referring to playing or talking about the instrument as a category.

üîπ Case 1: Talking About Playing an Instrument (General Use)

We always use "the" when referring to playing a musical instrument.

Examples:

  • He plays the guitar.
  • She is learning the piano.
  • Do you play the violin?

üìù This is because we're referring to the instrument type in general, not a specific one.

üîπ Case 2: Talking About the Instrument Itself (General Statement)

Even in general informative statements (like your sentence), we still use "the" to refer to the instrument as a category.

Your sentence:

‚ùå "Guitar is one of the most popular musical instruments in the world."
‚úÖ "The guitar is one of the most popular musical instruments in the world."

Here, "the guitar" represents the entire category of guitars, not a specific one.

üîπ When "the" is NOT used:

We do not use "the" when:

  • Talking about music in general (not an instrument).
  • Talking without an article in lists:
    e.g., ‚ÄúHe enjoys music like jazz, rock, and classical.‚Äù
    e.g., ‚ÄúGuitars and violins are popular instruments.‚Äù (here it‚Äôs plural)

‚úÖ Final Tip:

  • Use "the" before singular names of musical instruments, especially when playing or referring to the instrument type.
  • Don't use "the" before plural instruments or in non-specific general categories.

üìò Explanation:

  • ‚ÄúHeaven‚Äù is a proper noun when referring to the spiritual or religious concept of paradise.

‚úÖ Why ‚Äúthe Parliament‚Äù is used:

We use ‚Äúthe‚Äù before Parliament not because it is a monument or historical building, but because it refers to a specific institution‚Äîthe legislative body of a country.

  • ‚ÄúThe Parliament‚Äù refers to India‚Äôs central legislative authority (or any country‚Äôs official legislature).
  • It‚Äôs a unique, specific entity, hence the definite article ‚Äúthe‚Äù is required.

üìò Examples:

  • ‚úÖ He is a member of the Parliament.
  • ‚úÖ The Prime Minister addressed the Parliament today.

‚ùå Common Misconception:

Some learners think ‚Äúthe‚Äù is used because Parliament is a building or monument. That‚Äôs not accurate.

  • If you‚Äôre talking about the building itself as a tourist spot, you might say:
  • ‚ÄúWe visited the Parliament House in New Delhi.‚Äù

But in general usage, ‚ÄúParliament‚Äù is treated as a governing body, not a monument.
